headline.main: Tourist and 2 Others on Way to Space Station

results.snippet: Charles Simonyi, a software developer, began his second paid trip to the International Space Station on Thursday.
results.lead_paragraph: With the shuttle Discovery safely away from the International Space Station, a Russian Soyuz rocket blasted off Thursday from the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan carrying two fresh crew members and a wealthy space tourist. Under an overcast sky, the Soyuz TMA-14 spacecraft roared to life with a burst of flame and smoke at 7:49 a.m. Eastern time and smoothly climbed away from the same launch pad used by Yuri Gagarin at the dawn of the space age.

results.lead_paragraph: With the shuttle Discovery safely away from the International Space Station, a Russian Soyuz rocket blasted off Thursday from the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan carrying two fresh crew members and a wealthy space tourist. Under an overcast sky, the Soyuz TMA-14 spacecraft roared to life with a burst of flame and smoke at 7:49 a.m. Eastern time and smoothly climbed away from the same launch pad used by Yuri Gagarin at the dawn of the space age.

headline.main: Staying Put On Earth, Taking a Step To Mars

results.snippet: A crew of six people in Moscow will be isolated for 105 days on a simulated flight to another world.
results.lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, six people will be voluntarily locked into a cloister of cramped, hermetically sealed tubes woven inside a Moscow research facility the size of a high school gymnasium. They will eat dehydrated food, breathe recycled air and be denied conversation with practically everyone else but one another. And they must stay inside for 105 days.

results.abstract: As six would-be astronauts in Moscow began a 105-day experiment confined in a simulated spacecraft, word circulated that life aboard the International Space Station these days is far less fun than it used to be.
results.snippet: As six would-be astronauts in Moscow began a 105-day experiment confined in a simulated spacecraft, word circulated that life aboard the International Space Station these days is far less fun than it used to be.

byline.original: By MICHAEL SCHWIRTZ and ROBERT MACKEY

results.lead_paragraph: As a hatch door closed behind six would-be astronauts in Moscow on Tuesday, sealing them in for the first of 105 days of confinement in a simulated spacecraft -- as part of an experiment to see how humans might one day cope with very long trips to Mars -- word circulated that life aboard the International Space Station these days is far less fun than it used to be. The problem, it seems, is that new rules, introduced by American and Russian authorities, now forbid astronauts and cosmonauts from sharing their food with each other and even discourage them from using each other's toilets.
